III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Staff responsibilities
Title
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12207
Section • (3) An agency shall require that social service workers be
Description directly responsible for all the following activities:
• (a) Placing and supervising children in out-of-home
care. Social service workers shall work directly with
the children, their families, and other relevant
individuals and be primarily responsible for the
development, implementation, and review of service
plans for the children and their families.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation It is alleged that the agency is not supervising a child who is
hospitalized and is not seeking mental health services for her.
Investigation The Chief Administrator of the agency was notified by
telephone of the complaint on 07/01/24. The Chief
Administrator was to forward contact information of various
agency staff who could provide detailed information.
The agency Child Welfare Director was interviewed via
telephone on 0702/24. The Child Welfare Director, hereafter
referred to as Director, provided the following information. Foster
Youth A was hospitalized on 06/15/24 at Corewell Lakeland
hospital. The Director reported the agency was collaborating with
Corewell Hospital in providing supervision of Foster Youth A while
she was hospitalized. The Director reported that during a June 18,
2024, phone call with the hospital Clinical Nurse Supervisor,
supervision of Foster Youth A was discussed, and the Clinical
Nurse Supervisor informed Director the hospital has staff who can
help with supervision of Foster Youth A. The Director reported that
during a 06/28/24 phone call with Hospital Social Worker, she was
informed by Hospital Social Worker that the agency needed to
provide 24/7 supervision of Foster Youth A starting immediately.
The Director reported she questioned the directive of Hospital
Social Worker and telephoned the hospital and spoke with Chief
Nurse of Corewell South, hereafter referred to as Chief Nurse,
later in the day of 06/28/24. The Director reported Chief Nurse
stated the hospital could provide staffing supervision of Foster
Youth A particularly since agency staff would have to drive
2

significant distances to provide supervision coverage. The Director
added that Chief Nurse stated the hospital could provide
supervision of Foster Youth A for the weekend of 06/28/24
through 06/30/24.
The Director reported on 07/01/24 she again spoke via telephone
with the Chief Nurse. The Director reported that the Chief Nurse
informed her that Hospital Social Worker was misinformed, and a
complaint should not have been made.
The Director reported during the hospital stay of Foster Youth A
the agency had been actively seeking mental health services for
Foster Youth A as well as post hospital placement. The Director
reported that placement in a foster home for Foster Youth A had
been secured as 07/02/24 and placement would occur on
07/04/24.
The Complainant was interviewed via telephone on 08/15/24.
The Complainant reported the hospital had requested mental
health services for Foster Youth A and the agency said they would
connect with Community Mental Health (CMH) for services. The
Complainant reported after she had filed the complaint against the
agency, she learned they had been making efforts to secure
services for Foster Youth A. The Complainant reported
communication was not very good between the agency and the
hospital therefore they did not know efforts for services for Foster
Youth A were occurring.
The Complainant reported during the end of the hospital stay for
Foster Youth A, the agency was providing supervision along with
hospital staff. They reported there was frustration that the agency
was not seeking services or a placement for Foster Youth A.
Staff 1, the agency foster care worker for Foster Youth A, was
interviewed via telephone on 08/15/24. Staff 1 reported the
agency was providing supervision of Foster Youth A. Staff 1
reported she had been working on securing services for Foster
Youth A and the plan had been for Foster Youth A to start
services with CMH. Staff 1 reported she has documents reflecting
the agency efforts to secure services and also a supervision
schedule for Foster Youth A.
The Foster Care Supervisor was interviewed via telephone on
08/20/24. The Foster Care Supervisor, hereafter referred to as,
Supervisor, provided the following information. The Supervisor
3

reported that initially the hospital had said they have the staff to
supervise Foster Youth A and then they said they didn’t. The
Supervisor reported the agency sent staff from the Benton Harbor
office sometime after Foster Youth A’s admission to provide 9AM-
5PM supervision. The Supervisor reported an agency staff
providing supervision would not leave supervision duty until a
hospital staff arrived to begin supervision. The Supervisor
reported there never was a “gap” in supervision between hospital
staff and agency staff.
The Supervisor reported while Foster Youth A was residing in
Kent County she was receiving mental health services, but those
services could not be provided once Foster Youth A entered the
hospital. The Supervisor reported the agency was working to
secure mental health services for Foster Youth A from another
provider. The Supervisor reported Foster Youth A was to become
a resident of a different county and would enter a foster home
there upon her discharge from the hospital.
The Hospital Social Worker was interviewed on 08/15/24.
Foster Youth A was admitted to the hospital on 06/14/24 and
discharged on 07/04/24. The Hospital Social Worker reported
supervision of Foster Youth A was being provided by hospital staff
and the agency and did not report there were any gaps in
supervision.
The Chief Nurse of Corewell South was interviewed via
telephone on 08/28/24. The Chief Nurse stated she was directly
involved in the case and management of Foster Youth A and
supervised the hospital section where Foster Youth A was
located. The Chief Nurse apologized and stated, “Filing this
complaint was a mistake and it never should have been filed”. The
Chief Nurse reported it is the hospitals responsibility to provide
adequate supervision of youth hospitalized. The Chief Nurse
reported she was in conversation with the agency Director on
06/28/24 and informed her the hospital would take back
supervision of Foster Youth A. The Chief Nurse reported as this
conversation was occurring an agency staff had arrived to provide
supervision from 4:00PM-11:00PM. The Chief Nurse reported she
informed the Director the agency staff could finish the shift at
11:00 PM and the hospital would then take back full supervision
responsibility of Foster Youth A until her discharge. The Chief
Nurse did not report that there were any gaps in supervision of
Foster Youth A. The Chief Nurse reiterated that the hospital had
made a mistake in filing a complaint as there was a
miscommunication within the hospital team. The Chief Nurse
4

reiterated the agency was working with the hospital in a
collaborative way to provide coverage for Foster Youth A. The
Chief Nurse reported the agency staff were having to travel hours
to provide supervision and she felt this was unnecessary.
The Chief Nurse reported the agency was actively working on
securing services for Foster Youth A however details were
sometimes not provided to hospital staff and communication could
have been better. The Chief Nurse concluded the interview
reporting the hospital and Catholic Charities have a good working
relationship and have resolved any communication issues.
DOCUMENT REVIEW:
• Foster Youth A’s case file. Social work contacts were
reviewed from 06/18/24 to 07/01/24. A 06/28/24 contact
documents a phone call between the agency Director and
the Chief Nurse and agency efforts to secure a placement
for Foster Youth A were discussed. Another social work
contact dated 06/28/24 documents the Chief Nurse
informed the Director that hospital staff would begin
providing supervision at 11:00 PM on 06/28/24.
• Review of emails. An email dated 06/28/24 from the Child
Welfare Director to seven hospital staff details agency
staffing supervision for Foster Youth A for the weekend
starting 06/28/24.
Analysis The Child Welfare Director, Foster Care Supervisor, and Staff 1
reported the agency was working with the hospital in providing
supervision. The Chief Nurse reported that it was a mistake to file
a complaint as the agency was working with the hospital in
providing supervision. The Chief Nurse reported it is the hospitals
responsibility to provide supervision and released the agency from
this responsibility on 06/28/24.
Documents reviewed indicate the agency was attempting to
provide 24/7 weekend supervision of Foster Youth A.
The Child Welfare Director, Foster Care Supervisor, and Staff 1
reported the agency was working to secure a placement and
services for Foster Child A. Complainant reported after she had
filed the complaint, she learned the agency had been making
efforts to secure a placement and services for Foster Child A. The
Chief Nurse reported the agency had been making efforts to
5

secure a placement and services for Foster Child A but specifics
could have been communicated.
Technical Assistance: Technical assistance was provided
regarding improving communication with hospital staff should an
agency foster youth be hospitalized in the future. Specific details
regarding placement efforts as well as efforts to secure services
should be shared with hospital staff throughout the child’s stay.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
